title: 105_hr1450
content:
The Joint Resolution approved on March 24, 1976, amends the Covenant To Establish a Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in Political Union with the United States of America by adding a new section regarding the labeling of textile fiber products. The Joint Resolution approved on March 24, 1976, added a new section regarding the labeling of textile fiber products. Textile fiber products must meet wage and labor compliance requirements to be labeled as 'Made in the USA'. Non-compliant products are considered misbranded under the Textile Fiber Products Identification Act. The Textile Fiber Products Identification Act (15 U.S.C. 70 et seq.) defines 'direct labor' as work involving the preparation, assembly, processing, packaging, or transportation of textile fiber products, excluding supervisory, management, security, or administrative tasks. The Textile Fiber Products Identification Act defines 'direct labor' as work involving textile fiber products, excluding supervisory or administrative tasks. SEC. 8. MINIMUM WAGE. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 applies to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands with specific minimum wage provisions, starting at $3.55 per hour until it reaches the federal minimum wage rate. The minimum wage rate in the Northern Mariana Islands will increase to match the federal minimum wage rate set by the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. "SEC. 9. APPLICABILITY OF IMMIGRATION LAWS." Section 506(a) of the Covenant applies Immigration and Nationality Act to entry into the Northern Mariana Islands. The Attorney General enforces this provision. For individuals entering for employment in specific industries, Federal statutes and regulations for Guam apply. The regulations for admission to Guam under section 101(a)(15)(H)(ii)(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act apply, with substitutions for terms like "United States resident workers" and "Guam". The Attorney General must coordinate with State and local law enforcement when deploying personnel to enforce these provisions. The report is required under section 4. The Secretary of the Interior must include a study on human and labor rights violations in the Northern Mariana Islands in the annual report to Congress. The study will assess the extent of violations, including forced labor, and efforts to address them. Local officials and organizations may be consulted during the study. SEC. 5. EFFECT ON OTHER LAW.

The provisions of paragraph (1) of section 3 shall be in addition to, but shall not otherwise modify, the requirements of the Textile Fiber Products Identification Act (15 U.S.C. 70 et seq.).

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATES.

The amendments related to labeling of textile fiber products, immigration of workers, and minimum wage will take effect on specific dates after the enactment of this Act. The immigration amendment will apply to individuals entering the Northern Mariana Islands after a 6-month period from the enactment date. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
